posts.cooked: I want to design and build a mini Swerve chassis for less than $200, any ideas about what to control it with and what motors to use (maybe outdated FRC electronics). Any help would be appreciated.

posts.name: Andrew Schreiber
posts.cooked:
You won’t be near FRC scale with that.

Swerve drivetrain for XRP | Download free 3D printable STL models

Is pretty close, but it’s going to be a whole new world of controls.

link_counts.title: Omnidirectional XRP Robot by WildWilly | Download free STL model | Printables.com

posts.cooked: IF you really want FRC scale, the closest you would come would be with some combination of microprocessors (pi, Arduino, etc) with NerdSwerve and some donated CIM motors and Talons. However, be aware that connectors, batteries, switches, and other hardware to make it probably eat up your budget before any other building can begin.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: if you want free motors: Free Motors and Other junk (I just found that thread not even a minute ago)

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked:
First question we should be asking is why do you want to build a mini swerve bot?   Is it to practice design and building skills.  Looks like 1701 is already a swerve enabled team so more than likely building the swerve mini bot is not to develop code for next year.

Please check out nerdswerve.com .  One of our students, who is now a graduating senior, went down this road and documented his work on that website.  It has code and CAD.

Please reach out if you have questions.  My one word of advice is to have the end in mind.  CIMs and mini CIM are fairly easily gotten these days because they are pretty useless for competition robots.  If you spend all your time developing a platform around these types of motors, you might find that all the things you learn may not be directly applicable to a competition robot.

Best of luck.
I want to build this as a personal project, although I do want 1701 to build a NERDswerve chassis over the offseason to give our underclassmen something to do (and get a cool bot to mess around with)
